name: hard coal, import from AU | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18572/documentation

This dataset describes the transport needed for an average export of Australian hard coal to Northern America. Average coal losses and related emissions during transport and storage are included. The latter are based on generic estimates as no geography-specific data was available. The coal is transported from the mines by train to nine large coal-loading terminals at the coast of Queensland and New South Wales. Average distances of 250 km and 12000 km are estimated for train and transoceanic freight transport respectively. Of the rail transport, a smaller amount (50km) is already covered in the domestic market for hard coal dataset, only the additional transport needed (200km) for coal exports is covered in this dataset. ;More than 70% of Australia’s annual coal production is exported.Trade volumes are based on 2015 import data according to the United Nations (comtrade.org).;;Note: Discrepancies of hard coal trade volumes between different statistical sources as well as between import and export statistics of the same source are primarily due to differences in coal classification methodologies, which are not uniform on a global basis. They also occur because of coal in-transit, coal that is unaccounted for, and reporting discrepancies by importing and exporting countries.

Starting at the gate of the hard coal mine, this dataset includes the transport, re-loading and storage specific to coal exports/imports in the respective geographies. This means it includes 1.) any transport between the hard coal mine and the border of the exporting country which is required in addition to the transport needs of the domestic “market for hard coal”, 2.) the transport through transit countries (if applicable), 3.) the transoceanic freight shipping (if applicable) and 4.) any transport between the border of the importing country and the consumers which is required in addition to the transport needs of the domestic coal market.


The activity ends with the delivery of hard coal to the domestic market of the importing country.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The trade volumes represented in this dataset are based on 2015 UN trade statistics retrieved online from comtrade.org.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This datasets models the import of hard coal from Australia to North America.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The coal is transported from the mines by train to nine large coal-loading terminals at the coast of Queensland and New South Wales. An average distance of 250 km for train transport is based on data from the Australian Railway Association (BITRE, 2014). A distance of 9000 km transoceanic freight transport is estimated as average distance between the major ports for ex-/importing coal in the respective country along freight shipping routes.;Reference(s): Bureau of Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Economics (BITRE), 2014, Trainline 2, Statistical Report, Canberra ACT.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature research. The trade volumes were retrieved from UN statistics at comtrade.org for the commodity codes 270111 (Coal; anthracite, whether or not pulverised, but not agglomerated), 270112 (Coal; bituminous, whether or not pulverised, but not agglomerated), 270119 (Coal; (other than anthracite and bituminous), whether or not pulverised but not agglomerated.

flow.name: hard coal
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

exchanges.description: The weighted average transport distance from five major mines to the coal exporting ports of 1 kg exported hard coal in Australia is 250km of which 50km are already covered in the market for hard coal, AU. Data reported by the Austialian Railway Association. Reference(s): Bureau of Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Economics (BITRE), 2014, Trainline 2, Statistical Report, Canberra ACT. Minor shares of hard coal extracted in Australia are transported by lorry, if the mines are not located in proximity to rail infrastructure. It is here assumed that lorry transport supplies domestic consumers and all export coal is transported by train.

exchanges.description:
Compensation for product losses. For a lack of more recent or specific data this value is based on the estimation by Dones et al. (2007) that generally 0.2% of losses occure during coal transport. It is assumed that these losses are released to the environment in the form of particulate matter > 10 micrometer. Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen
von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von
Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die
Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

defaultProvider.category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

exchanges.description:
Rough estimate using Google Earth and freight shipping maps. Australian coal is mainly exported from East Australia where the major ports are Newcastle, Hay Point, Dalrymple Bay, Gladstone, Brisbane and Abbot Point (opensea.org, 2017). 
Reference(s): 
opensea.org. 2017. Blog: COAL: THE “BLACK GOLD” OF DRY BULK SHIPPING. Accessed online at: https://opensea.pro/blog/shipping-coal, 13 November 2017.
